git init: Initialize a new Git repository in the current directory.
git clone: Copy an existing repository from a remote URL into a new folder.
git status: Show which files are staged, unstaged, or untracked.
git add: Stage a specific file for the next commit.
Stage all modified and untracked files in the current directory.
git commit: Record staged changes as a new snapshot in history.
git commit -m: Commit staged changes and set the message inline.
git log --oneline: View commit history as a concise list.
git checkout: Switch to another branch or restore files.
git checkout -b: Create a new branch and switch to it.
git merge: Combine another branch into the current branch.
git rebase: Replay commits on top of another base branch.
git stash pop: Apply and remove the last stash.
git tag: Mark a specific commit with a tag.
git tag -a: Create an annotated tag with author and message.
git reset --soft: Move HEAD back but keep changes staged.
git revert: Create a commit that undoes a previous commit.
